dc:description:
DES was originally evaluated for DCM by ClinGen DCM GCEP on August 14, 2020. Evidence of the association of this gene with DCM was re-evaluated on February 23, 2025. As a result, the classification did not change. A summary of the information contributing to the classification of the gene at the time of re-evaluation is summarized herein. 

DES was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) in 1999 (Li et al., 1999, PMID 10430757).Desmin is the major Intermediate filament that integrates the sarcolemma, Z disk and nuclear membrane in sarcomeres and regulates sarcomeric architecture. Disease-associated desmin variants cause an accumulation of disorganized intracytoplasmic aggregates containing desmin and other cytoskeletal proteins. Human genetic evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data. At least 18 heterozygous variants (including missense, nonsense, splice-site) have been reported in humans with autosomal dominant DCM (Li et al., 1999, PMID 10430757; Miyamoto et al., 2001, PMID 11728149; Taylor et al., 2007, PMID 17325244; Tse et al., 2013, PMID 23300193; Gigli et al., 2019, PMID 31514951; Brodehl et al., 2016, PMID 26724190; van Spaendonck-Zwarts et al., 2013, PMID 23349452; Weihl et al., 2015 PMID 25557463; van Tintelen et al. 2009, PMID 19879535 . This gene-disease relationship has been studied in one large case-control study at the aggregate variant level (Mazzarotto et al., 2020, PMID 31983221). There was no enrichment of rare DES variants in two DCM cohorts compared to ExAC derived controls. In addition, this gene-disease association is supported by animal models, expression studies, and in vitro functional assays (Milner et al., 1999, PMID 10591032; Taylor et al., 2007, PMID 17325244; Tse et al., 2013, PMID 23300193; Brodehl et al., 2016, PMID 26724190. Of note, this gene has also been implicated in arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) and myofibrillar myopathy 1 (MFM1) and has been assessed separately for these distinct phenotypes (Definitive, ARVC, August 25, 2017; Moderate, MFM1, November 9, 2018). In summary, DES is definitively associated with autosomal dominant DCM. This has been repeatedly demonstrated in both the research and clinical diagnostic settings, and has been upheld over time. This classification was originally approved by the ClinGen Dilated Cardiomyopathy Working Group on August 14th, 2020 (SOP Version 7). This written summary was updated on 02/23/2025 and approved by the DCM GCEP on 05/30/2025.
curationReasonDescription: Evidence for DES variants being causal for DCM have been replicated over time. Discussed and approved by the DCM GCEP on 08.14.2020

evidence.dc:description: No functional or segregation data for the variant; therefore the score was reduced from the default 0.5 to 0.1 during original curation using SOP version 7.
Expression studies in SW13 cells, human coronary artery smooth muscle cells and neonatal rat cardiac myocytes showed intracytoplasmic desmin aggregates. Thus, the variant is considered pathogenic.
No functional or segregation data for the variant; therefore the score was reduced from the default 0.5 to 0.1 during original curation using SOP version 7.

The in vitro analysis using cell transfection experiments and atomic force microscopy (AFM) demonstrated that mutant desmin p.L136P cannot form extended filaments. These experiments were supported by molecular modeling and immuno-histochemistry of explanted human heart tissue of the patient.
No functional or segregation data for the variant; therefore the score was reduced from the default 0.5 to 0.1 during original curation using SOP 7.

Expression studies of Arg350Trp variant in SW13 cells, human coronary artery smooth muscle cells and neonatal rat cardiac myocytes showed intracytoplasmic desmin aggregates. Thus, the variant is considered pathogenic.
This case is likely the same case as the 55y/o male patient with DCM in Taylor et al. Circulation 2007 (PMID 17325244), which was already assigned a score for genetic evidence of this variant.

Functional evidence for the variant provided by Pica et al. Neuromuscul Disord 2008, PMID 18061454. DES-p.Ser13Phe-related myopathy was identified in a Chinese man with complete AV block and mild proximal/distal limb weakness. Family members carrying the mutation showed a similar or milder phenotype. The mutation is located at a protein kinase-C phosphorylation site within a highly conserved nonapeptide sequence in the head domain of the desmin protein. The myopathy was confirmed with biopsy, showing areas of disorganised desmin immunostaining. Electron microscopy revealed disorganized filaments interspersed with microgranular dense structures, resembling spheroid bodies. Oval bodies with a dense core and a lighter halo were also present, with an appearance resembling cytoplasmic bodies. BHK-21 and MCF-7 cells transfected with either wild type or S13F mutant desmin cDNA constructs showed a fine desmin filamentous network in the cytoplasm. Many of the BHK-21 and MCF-7 cells transfected with DES-S13F mutant also showed large accumulations of desmin-immunopositive material with the filamentous network. Such desmin accumulations were absent/very rare in cells transfected with WT desmin. Based on this functional evidence the variant found in this patient with DCM was considered as pathogenic and awarded full default points.

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: DCM, biatrial enlargement and complete AV block, PM implantation at the age of 39, progressive bilateral upper and lower extremity distal weakness.

member.rdfs:label: III.3
member.detectionMethod: targeted sequencing of 38 neuromuscular genes that included LAMP2, VMA21, DES, MYOT, FLNC, VCP, LDB3, MATR3, BAG3, CRYAB, FHL1 and DNAJB6.
member.phenotypeFreeText: DCM, proximal and distal lower extremity weakness.

The Ile451Met variant appears to show incomplete penetrance. In Li et al. Circulation 1999, PMID 10430757, the variant segregated with DCM phenotype in 6 individuals. In Dalakas et al. NEJM 2000 (PMID: 10717012), In transfected cells, the mutant desmin was unable to form a filamentous network. Miyamoto et al. EHJ 2001, PMID: 11728149 showed that patients with the Ile451Met variant have desmin reactive deposits in cardiac biopsy. Thus, this variant was considered pathogenic.
No functional or segregation data for the variant; therefore the score was reduced from the default 0.5 to 0.1 during original curation using SOP version 7.

EHJ 2001, PMID: 11728149 showed that patients with the Ile451Met variant have desmin reactive deposits in cardiac biopsy. Thus, this variant was considered pathogenic.

Functional evidence for the variant provided by Pica et al. Neuromuscul Disord 2008, PMID 18061454. DES-p.Ser13Phe-related myopathy was identified in a Chinese man with complete AV block and mild proximal/distal limb weakness. Family members carrying the mutation showed a similar or milder phenotype. The mutation is located at a protein kinase-C phosphorylation site within a highly conserved nonapeptide sequence in the head domain of the desmin protein. The myopathy was confirmed with biopsy, showing areas of disorganised desmin immunostaining. Electron microscopy revealed disorganized filaments interspersed with microgranular dense structures, resembling spheroid bodies. Oval bodies with a dense core and a lighter halo were also present, with an appearance resembling cytoplasmic bodies. BHK-21 and MCF-7 cells transfected with either wild type or S13F mutant desmin cDNA constructs showed a fine desmin filamentous network in the cytoplasm. Many of the BHK-21 and MCF-7 cells transfected with DES-S13F mutant also showed large accumulations of desmin-immunopositive material with the filamentous network. Such desmin accumulations were absent/very rare in cells transfected with WT desmin. Based on this functional evidence the variant found in this patient with DCM was considered as pathogenic and awarded full default points.
Variant scored 0.5 default for other variant type per SOP 7, which was used during the original curation.

The Ile451Met variant appears to show incomplete penetrance. In Li et al. Circulation 1999, PMID 10430757, the variant segregated with DCM phenotype in 6 individuals. In Dalakas et al. NEJM 2000 (PMID: 10717012), In transfected cells, the mutant desmin was unable to form a filamentous network. Miyamoto et al. EHJ 2001, PMID: 11728149 showed that patients with the Ile451Met variant have desmin reactive deposits in cardiac biopsy. Thus, this variant was considered pathogenic.
No functional or segregation data for the variant; therefore the score was reduced from the default 0.5 to 0.1 during original curation using SOP version 7.

Muscle biopsy demonstrated marked variability in muscle fiber size along with fibers containing vacuoles and internal nuclei, rare fibers also had eosinophilic inclusions. Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide tetrazolium reductase (NADH-TR) staining showed disorganization of internal architecture, moth-eaten fibers, small accumulations of endomembrane.
No functional or segregation data for the variant; therefore the score was reduced from the default 0.5 to 0.1 during original curation using SOP version 7.

Although these patients were screened for variants in other relevant DCM-associated genes (23 in a panel), the clinical phenotype of the patients is not well characterized, and the demographic data is not available in the published data. There is no functional or segregation evidence for these variants. Therefore the score for each variant was reduced from 0.5 (default) to 0.1 during original curation using SOP version 7.
Functional data providing evidence for variant pathogenicity provided by Taylor et al. Circulation 2007 PMID 17325244
No functional or segregation data for the variant; therefore the score was reduced from the default 0.5 to 0.1 during original curation using SOP version 7.
Variant scored 0.5 default for other variant type per SOP 7, which was used during the original curation.

The Ile451Met variant appears to show incomplete penetrance. In Dalakas et al. NEJM 2000 (PMID: 10717012), In transfected cells, the mutant desmin was unable to form a filamentous network. Miyamoto et al. EHJ 2001, PMID: 11728149 showed that patients with the Ile451Met variant have desmin reactive deposits in cardiac biopsy. Thus, this variant was considered pathogenic.

Although these patients were screened for variants in other relevant DCM-associated genes (23 in a panel), the clinical phenotype of the patients is not well characterized, and the demographic data is not available in the published data. There is no functional or segregation evidence for these variants. Therefore the score for each variant was reduced from 0.5 (default) to 0.1 during original curation using SOP version 7.

Over-expression of A285V-DES in HEK293 cells resulted in diffuse abnormal DES aggregation in up to 70% of cells without clear organized filament network. Immunohistological and electron microscopy studies demonstrated diffuse abnormal DES aggregations in DCM-induced-pluripotent stem cell (iPSC)-derived cardiomyocytes, and control-iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes transduced with A285V-DES. DCM-iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes also exhibited functional abnormalities in vitro.

Muscle biopsy: On modified gomori trichrome staining, red-rimmed vacuoles were seen in both large and small fibers. Some vacuoles were positive for acid phosphatase and non-specific esterase. Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) staining accumulated in some fibers but was notably absent from vacuolar structures. Sarcolemmal membrane proteins including dystrophin, caveolin-3, α-, β-, δ-, γ-sarcoglycan and the sarcolemmal membrane associated protein α2-laminin were present at the sarcolemmal membrane but also had abnormal staining within the sarcoplasm as vacuolated structures or along invaginating sarcolemmal membranes. While vacuoles lined by sarcolemmal proteins were present in ~10% of fibers, autophagic markers such as LC3 were present as large intrasarcoplasmic inclusions or on vacuoles within >60% of myofibers. Desmin immunostaining was present as small and large aggregates throughout many fibers. MHC class I expression was not increased on the plasma membrane of myofibers and C5b-9 complement immunostaining was only present in scattered necrotic fibers (not shown).
evidence.rdfs:label: Histopathology and Immunohistophathology

evidence.dc:description: Three randomly selected areas fromthe heterozygous DES-p.L136P patient (A–C) and of a control sample (D–F) were shown. Disorganized and blurry desmin staining at the Z-bandswas prominent in the DES-p.L136P patient but not in the control sample. The localization of desmin at the intercalated disk seems comparable in both samples.
evidence.rdfs:label: Immunohistochemical analysis of left ventricular myocardial

evidence.dc:description: Only poor co-localization of DES with cardiac Troponin-T, a-Actinin or F-actin and incapable of assembling into DES network was observed in DCM-iPSC-derived CMs, whilst diffuse isolated aggregations of DES-positive protein were observed in up to 70% of these cells.
evidence.rdfs:label: DCM-iPSC

evidence.dc:description: DES-p.L136P results in desmin aggregated in cardiomyocytes. Desmin aggregates result in abnormal cardiomyocyte filament network formation and dilated cardiomyopathy.
evidence.rdfs:label: fluorescence images of transfected cells

evidence.dc:description: The paper provides evidence for desmin aggregate formation in three types of cells transfected with the Asp312Asn mutant: SW13 cells, human coronary artery smooth muscle cells, and neonatal rat cardiac myocytes. The evidence combined is assigned a full default 1.0 point.
DES-Asp312Asn results in desmin aggregated in cardiomyocytes. Desmin aggregates result in abnormal cardiomyocyte filament network formation and dilated cardiomyopathy
evidence.rdfs:label: Transfection of Asp312Asn in neonatal rat cardiac myocytes

evidence.dc:description:
This is a model of Des null mice, rather than a model based on a human DES mutation associated with DCM. Therefore, the default score of 2.0 points was reduced to 1.0. 
This score was assigned because 1) the paper includes evidence for different levels (macroscopic, histological, Northern blot); and 2) the mechanism of DES-DCM is thought to be loss-of-function, similar to Des null mice.

DES null (-/-) mice showed severe macroscopic enlargement of the heart, severe dilation of the chambers, compared to wilt-type (+/+) mice. Northern analysis of cardiac gene expression in the ventricles of wild-type (+/+) and desmin null (-/-) mice at 1 month and 6 months of age demonstrated induction of atrial natriuretic factor (ANF) and a-skeletal actin (a-Sk act) and decrease in phospholamban (PLB) and SERCA 2A; (18S) 18S RNA.
evidence.rdfs:label: Generation of Des-/- mice
